Deoxygenation of pyrolysis vapor from palm fruit cake by different catalysts was prior investigated by using Ni/γ-Al2O3, Mo/γ-Al2O3, and NiMo/γ-Al2O3 prepared by wet impregnation method. NiMo/γ-Al2O3 showing the highest degree of deoxygenation (%DOD) activity was subsequently mixed with metal oxides: CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2. Effects of the catalysts on upgrading of pyrolysis vapor from palm fruit cake at 450°C under N2 atmosphere in a semi-batch process were investigated. The oil products were analyzed for CHNO elements by elemental analyzer, chemical compositions by a gas chromatograph coupled to a mass spectrometer (GC-MS), and higher heating values (HHV) by Dulong's equation. Catalysts have been characterized and discussed related to the product yields and properties. Acidity and acid strength of the catalyst mixture play an important role on the products. NiMo/γ-Al2O3 improved properties of the crude bio-oil by increasing organic phase yield, %DOD, and HHV. Addition of CeO2 to NiMo/γ-Al2O3 reduced phenol compound in the liquid products while addition of TiO2 to NiMo/γ-Al2O3 provided high aromatics and hydrocarbons comparable to those obtained from NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2. Addition of ZrO2 to NiMo/γ-Al2O3 exhibited the highest organic phase yield (%), %DOD (71%), and HHV (37 MJ/kg). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Key words Deoxygenation Palm fruit cake Alumina Nickel Molybdenum Metal Oxides 1 Introduction Due to the prediction of a shortage of fossil fuels in the near future, clean energy sources such as wind, hydroelectric power, solar, hydrogen, nuclear power and biomass are of great interest [1,2]. Among these, biomass is recognized as an important source of alternative energy, particularly in developing countries. Agricultural residue is cheap, abundant, and does not require much effort to collect [3]. Moreover, biomass has a negligible content of sulfur, nitrogen, and ash. Biomass consists mainly of cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin. Palm fruit cake in this study was from the extraction process in a palm oil industry. It was readily available and considered a good source of biomass. Pyrolysis is a choice to convert biomass to bio-oil. It is the thermal decomposition of the organic matter in the absence of oxygen to produce renewable energy resources in forms of liquid (bio-oil), solid char, and gases [4]. Bio-oil, a dark brown liquid with an unpleasant odor, has both advantages and disadvantages. It is a complex and chemically unstable mixture. When it is used for combustion, the emissions of sulfur oxides (SOx) and nitrogen oxides are less than those from petroleum diesel [5]. Bio-oil is an alternative to petroleum-based fractions for the production of fuels and high value-added chemicals. The major organic compounds of the bio-oils are oxygenates like acids, alcohols, ethers, ketones, aldehydes, phenols, esters, sugars, furans, and nitrogen compounds. The oxygenated compounds in bio-oil consist of carbonyl, carboxyl, and phenolic groups. Bio-oil is not suitable for commercial transportation due to its corrosiveness (acidity), instability, high water and oxygen contents, low heating value, and high viscosity [6,7]. Conversion of bio-oil to transportation fuels needs its upgrading to increase heating value, thermal stability, and reduce viscosity and the content of oxygenates. Therefore, upgrading of pyrolytic oils is of high necessity. Many efficient processes have been proposed for upgrading of bio-oil, such as dehydration, deoxygenation, hydrodeoxygenation, supercritical fluids, steam reforming, chemical extraction, esterification, hydrogenation, depolymerization, and alkylation [6,8]. Two possible ways to upgrade bio-oil are: (1) treatment with zeolites at atmospheric pressure and high temperatures and (2) catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) under high pressure. The HDO is extensively studied as it is based on the well-known hydrotreatment process of petroleum fractions and appears to be very effective for the bio-oil upgrading [9]. In hydrotreating in oil refinery, nickel-molybdenum supported on the surface of oxidic supports such as alumina (Al2O3) and silica-alumina (SiO2–Al2O3) catalysts are extensively used [10]. The commercial catalysts are in general consists of NiMo or CoMo metals supported on alumina. Although SBA-15 and AC-supported NiMo have very high surface area compared to the alumina-supported catalyst, the NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst has a higher pore diameter and pore volume with an appropriate surface area. The NiMo catalyst supported on mesoporous alumina showed the highest hydrotreating and hydrocracking conversions [11]. The high activity of NiMo/Al2O3 in hydrogenation processes, especially at low temperatures, was reported by Gandarias et al. [12] and Platanitis et al. [13]. The special interest in NiMo/Al2O3 catalysts is in fact that they are widely available and used in the petroleum industry for hydrotreatment of light to heavy fractions, they are relatively cheap, and they appear very active and attractive for HDO applications [11]. For deoxygenation reaction of bio-oil, even though hydrogen gas was not used, it was reported that hydrogen gas was produced from steam reforming of the aqueous phase in the bio-oil using different catalysts. Yan et al. [14] used Ni/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst to produce H2 in steam reforming process at 800°C and water-to-bio-oil ratio (W/B) of 4.9 in a fixed-bed reactor. The best performance exhibited when the Ni and Ce load were 12% and 7.5% by weight, respectively, the H2 yield was 69.7%. Moreover, Han-u-domlarpyos et al. [15] investigated catalytic deoxygenation of pyrolysis oil from palm shell over NiMoS/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in a fixed-bed reactor at a temperature range 350–450°C. The results showed that the oxygenated compound in the bio-oil product were mainly phenol and its derivatives. Kubička and Kaluža [16] conducted pyrolysis of pine wood in a fixed-bed reactor, at 500°C, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 6 h−1, and reported that Ni-modified ZSM-5 increased the overall aromatic hydrocarbon yield and conversion of the pyrolysis vapor oxygenates over biomass/catalyst ratio 1 to 1. Moreover, increasing in Ni loading led to increasing in aromatic hydrocarbon production. Zulkepli et al. [17] have studied effect of various Ni loadings (5–100 wt% Ni) on hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS). It was reported that the incorporation of Ni into HMS has generated new acid sites of weak and moderate strengths. The incorporation of Ni loading into the HMS framework showed an increase in catalytic activity compared to that of HMS in the deoxygenation of triolein to produce a hydrocarbon fuel in the absence of hydrogen and solvent. Moreover, it was reported that 10 wt% Ni/HMS catalyst exhibited the highest conversion. Conversion of 92.5% and selectivity of 95.2% were achieved. The 10 wt% Ni/HMS exhibited a weak and strong level of acidity at 150–170 °C and 490–700 °C respectively. It was explained that the highest conversion received was due to the synergistic effect of Si-O-Ni bonding and high dispersion of NiO on HMS. This was explained that the high surface area and the interaction of HMS and NiO has enhanced the formation of additional acid sites. They have observed that 10 wt% Ni loading was highly dispersed on the HMS. CeO2, TiO2 and ZrO2 are very promising materials for industrial applications [18]. CeO2 has fluorite structure, in which the oxygen atoms are all co-planar, this allows oxygen atoms to diffuse rapidly through the lattice. CeO2 has been widely used as support. It improves thermal stability of the catalyst, metal dispersion, and suppresses coke formation due to a good oxygen storage capacity [19]. Some researchers informed that an addition of ZrO2 to CeO2 improved the redox capacity and used as a good support [20]. TiO2 is a non-toxic, stable, and low cost chemical. It is not only used as a catalyst support but also as an active site that impacts the catalytic performance. TiO2 is a weak acid support, mainly with Lewis acid properties since Bronsted acidity is not observed [21]. The Lewis acid sites have a tendency to attract the oxygen ion pair of the molecules, this leads to higher selectivity for the hydrogenated product. Using TiO2 as a catalyst to catalyze the transformation of guaiacol through demethylation, it was observed that hydrogenation was the main pathway. TiO2 performs as a reservoir of H atoms where H atoms can migrate from one reactant to another reactant. The hydrogen molecules adsorbed and dissociated on the metal surface can migrate to the TiO2 where they are trapped at surface defects. The H+ on TiO2 can be exchanged with H2 in the presence of the metal phase. The hydrogen spill-over enhances reduction and the hydrogenation ability of TiO2. Moreover, it was mentioned that TiO2 effectively prevents the growth and sintering of metal particles. Anatase, rutile, and brookite are the three main crystal polymorphs of TiO2. Each polymorph has different physical properties. Among the three polymorphs, rutile is the most stable phase under ambient temperature while anatase and brookite are metastable at all temperatures and will transform to rutile when they are heated. Most experimental work has been carried out with anatase or rutile. The presence of either or both of these phases leads to different activities for chemical reactions. Brookite is the least stable phase among the three thus it is seldom studied [21]. ZrO2 has been shown to inhibit sintering of some active components, due to its high mechanical strength and good thermal resistance. In addition, Yakovlev et al. [22] showed that CeO2 and ZrO2 were most effective additives because of possible additional activation of oxy-compounds on the surface. Kaewpengkrow et al. [23] used Al2O3, ZrO2, and TiO2, which have 2 phases: rutile and anatase for upgrading of bio-oil from Jatropha wastes. The results showed that Al2O3 and TiO2 (anatase) were the most effective metal oxides for increasing hydrocarbon while decreasing oxygenated compounds. Meanwhile Lu et al. [24] studied mesoporous ZrO2, TiO2, and SiO2 (SBA-15) for catalytic cracking of biomass in fast pyrolysis. ZrO2 was the best catalyst for improving the product properties. It was able to convert lignin-derived oligomers to monomeric phenolic compounds. In addition, it decreased anhydrosugars, linear aldehydes, and linear acid, while production of linear ketones, furans, hydrocarbons, and cyclopentanone was increased. Similarly, Lu et al. [25] studied the upgrading of bio-oil from poplar wood using 12 different catalysts over various meso- or macroporous supports. As a result, ZrO2 and TiO2 decreased phenol, organic acid, and anhydrous sugar while increasing hydrocarbons, ketones, and cyclopentanone. Likewise, Chen et al. [26] conducted deoxygenation of octanoic acid using hollow spherical Ni/ZrO2 in a nanoreactor. ZrO2 which had oxygen vacancies increased the conversion of octanoic acid to alkanes. Furthermore, Choi et al. [27] used WOx/Pt/TiO2 (WPT) catalyst for the deoxygenation of stearic acid, a model compound of free-fatty acid, and jatropha fatty acid, a real feed, to produce bio-jet fuel range alkane. The deoxygenation reaction was carried out in a batch reactor at 300°C for 3 h, and initial N2 pressure of 15 bar. It was reported that WPT enhanced degree of deoxygenation (%DOD) up to 86%. In our work, palm fruit cake was used as a source of biomass due to its abundance and availability in Thailand. The bio-oil produced from pyrolysis is well known for its low quality due to high acidity and low hydrocarbons. In line with the above discussion, NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were expected to lower acidity and increase hydrocarbon production. In addition, metal oxides CeO2, ZrO2, and TiO2 were added to NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, and the bio-oil properties were expected to be improved. The activity of NiMo/γ-Al2O3 promoted by CeO2, ZrO2, and TiO2 has not been reported. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Palm fruit cake (PFC) used in this study was a waste from a vegetable oil refining and bio-diesel plant. The oil palm fruit was squeezed to separate the crude palm oil and the palm fruit cake. PFC was a by-product from crude palm oil extraction process from the Chaipattana Foundation at Hua Hin District, Prachuab Khiri Khan Province. Prior to use, PFC was dried in an oven at 105°C for 24 hours and then crushed and sieved. Particles with dimensions less than 1 mm were used. The proximate analysis of PFC which includes moisture content (ASTM D1756-08), ash content (ASTM E11755-01), and volatile matter (ASTM E872-82) is shown in Table 1 . The ultimate analysis was determined by using a LECO model 628 Series CNH 2000 elemental analyzer for C, H, N, and O (by difference) contents. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Compositions of Ni and Mo on γ-Al2O3 were 10 wt% Ni and 10 wt% Mo. The amount of 10 wt% Ni on alumina was from the study of Zulkepli et al. [17]. They studied the use of Ni on mesoporous silica for deoxygenation of triolein into hydrocarbon-biofuel production. The use of 10 wt% of Ni/hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) catalyst exhibited the highest conversion of triolein into hydrocarbon-biofuel products compared to 5 wt%, 40 wt% of Ni/ HMS and 100 wt% of Ni. Moreover, the use of 10 wt% Mo on support was based on the content of Mo in a commercial NiMo/Al2O3 which contained 12.5 wt% Mo [9]. In addition, catalyst preparation method also affects activities of the catalysts. Lee et al. [28] have studied the effects of the catalyst preparation method and CeO2 particle morphology of Pt/CeO2 catalysts for the water–gas shift reaction. The Pt metal was loaded via either the incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method or the strong electrostatic adsorption (SEA) method. The results show preparation method strongly affects the catalyst activity. The catalyst prepared by IWI method showed higher catalytic activity than the SEA-prepared catalysts regardless of the morphology of the CeO2. Moreover, the cube-shaped-CeO2-based catalysts showed higher catalytic activities than the rod-shaped-CeO2-based catalysts regardless of the catalyst preparation method. Their results highlight the fact that the catalyst preparation method and the morphology of the CeO2 support strongly affects the key factors related to the catalytic activity in the water–gas shift reaction separately. Moreover, Gurbani et al. [29] has prepared 7 wt% CuO–CeO2 catalyst by conventional wet impregnation (WI) and deposition–precipitation (DP) methods. The catalyst from wet impregnation method has shown a great activity and selectivity, as well as high surface area and good interaction with CO for CO oxidation reaction, with a considerably small particle size. It shows that the interaction needed between metal and support for an efficient performance of the catalyst is obtained by such a simple wet impregnation method, also obtain large interface Cu–Ce where the CO is adsorbed and reacts to form CO2. Compared to the DP method which provides catalyst with very high dispersion, but the intimate contact between CuO and ceria is less active than that prepared by WI. Wet impregnation method is a common technique used for the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts, it is simple, cost effective and provides high catalytic activity. Therefore, the catalyst used in this study was simply prepared by wet impregnation method. 2.2.1 Ni γ-Al2O3 was obtained from Dong Yang (HK) group limited, Hongwa Nanometer, Guangzhou, China. It has a particle size of 15–20 nm, and a surface area of 220 m2/g. The 10 wt% of Ni on γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by wet impregnation method using Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (Extra pure, QRëC) as a precursor. 4.955 g of Ni(NO3)2.6H2O was dissolved in 15 ml deionized water. The precursor solution was added to 9 g γ-Al2O3 support, stirred at 80°C for 2 hours, dried in a hot air oven at 105°C overnight, and calcined at 500°C for 4 hours. 2.2.2 Mo / γ − A l 2 O 3 The 10 wt% Mo on γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by wet impregnation method identical to Ni/γ-Al2O3 preparation but using 1.8398 g (NH4)6Mo7O24.4H2O (UNIVAR, Purity 99%, grade AR) as a precursor. 2.2.3 NiMo / γ − A l 2 O 3 The 10 wt% Ni and 10 wt% Mo on γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by wet impregnation method using 4.955 g Ni(NO3)2.6H2O and 1.8398 g (NH4)6Mo7O24.4H2O as precursors. Both precursors were dissolved in 15 ml deionized water. The precursor solutions were then added to 8 g γ-Al2O3 support, stirred at 80°C for 2 hours, dried in a hot air oven at 105°C overnight, and calcined at 500°C for 4 hours. Prior to use, all the catalysts were reduced with H2 gas at 50 cm3/min, 700°C for 2 hours. 2.2.4 NiMo / γ − A l 2 O 3 / metal oxides ( Ce O 2 , Ti O 2 , and Zr O 2 ) The NiMo/γ-Al2O3 and metal oxide catalyst was prepared by simply mixing NiMo/γ-Al2O3 with metal oxide powder at a weight ratio of 1:1. Each experiment, 0.15 g NiMo/γ-Al2O3 was mixed with 0.15 g of each metal oxide including cerium (IV) oxide (99.0%, CeO2 (Aldrich), surface area of 196.6 m2/g, pore volume of 0.004 cm3/g, pore size 0.09 nm), titanium (IV) dioxide (98% anatase powder, TiO2 (Acros), surface area of 66.8 m2/g, pore volume of 0.002 cm3/g, pore size 0.075 nm), and zirconium (IV) dioxide (98.5%, ZrO2 (Acros), surface area of 184.6 m2/g, pore volume of 0.003 cm3/g, pore size 0.069 nm). The amount of catalyst used for each experiment was 0.3 g catalyst per 100 g palm fruit cake. Larger amount of catalyst can be used with an increase amount of biomass. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter of the catalysts were analyzed by an Autosorb-1 using multipoint BET. Images of the catalyst and the amounts of Ni and Mo were obtained by Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM)/Energy Dispersive X-Ray Spectrometer (EDS) and X-Ray Fluorescence Spectrometer (XRF), and the catalyst structure was analyzed by X-ray Diffractometer (XRD). Scanning electron micrographs of the fresh synthesized oxide catalysts were obtained from Philips XL 30 SEM with the energy dispersive X-ray of 13 kV and 10000x magnification. Prior to analysis, the samples were coated with carbon as a conducting material by using an Edwards Scancoat Six coating machine. X-ray diffraction patterns of oxides of NiMo/γ-Al2O3 were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance Powder Diffractometer using a Cu Ka radiation source at 40 kV 40 mA, a 2-theta (2 θ ) range of 20–80°, and a wavelength (λ) of 0.020449 Å. The crystal structure was determined in reference to ICDD PDF-2 (2011 version). TPR was performed to find the reduction temperature of the catalysts. H2-TPR profile of the NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst sample was conducted in Microactive for AutoChem II 2920 Version 6.01. About 0.2 g of NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was used for measurement. Temperature was increased up to 1000 °C with a 5 °C/min heating rate. A mixture of 10 mol % H2/Ar was introduced as a reducing agent at 30 cm3/min into the sample loop and was also used as a reference gas. The hydrogen consumption was detected by a thermal conductive detector. NH3-TPD analysis is available in 3 Flex version 5.2 analyzer from Micromeritics. For each experiment, an amount of 150−200 mg of catalyst sample was first pretreated for 1 h at 700 °C with a 10 mol% H2/Ar at a flow rate of 30 cm3/min. Then, the sample was cooled to 150 °C and brought to saturation using a 97 mol% NH3/3 mol% He gas mixture, at a 30 cm3/min flow rate for 1 h. After that, the NH3 flow was switched off. Then, 30 cm3/min of a pure inert gas (He) at 100 °C was contacted with the catalyst for 1 h extra, to remove the physically adsorbed NH3. The temperature was then raised to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, with NH3 being desorbed progressively. The NH3 concentration in the effluent gas was monitored by using a TCD. 2.4 Pyrolysis and upgrading processes 100 g of PFC was placed in a stainless steel vessel in a pyrolyser. Pyrolysis was carried out under N2 atmosphere with a N2 flow rate of 100 ml/min. The pyrolyser was heated by an electric furnace to the specified temperature (400, 450, or 500°C). The pyrolysis vapor passed through the empty tubular reactor (Fig. 1 ) which was at 400, 450 or 500°C, i.e. the same temperature. The pyrolyser was maintained at the specified temperature for 1 h. The condensable vapor products were condensed in a condenser which was maintained at 10°C. The liquid product was collected in a conical flask, which was immersed in an ice bath with salt at a temperature of about -5°C, while the uncondensed vapor left through a fume hood. The upgrading process was almost identical to the pyrolysis process, except that the tubular reactor (internal diameter of 7 mm) was loaded with catalyst (0.30-0.45 g catalyst/100 g biomass) and the temperature was adjusted to 450°C prior to pyrolysis of the biomass. The flow rate of N2 was 100 cm3/min, weight hourly space velocity of 2,000 cm3/g⋅h, and the pyrolysis reactor was heated by an electric furnace to 450°C. The pyrolysis vapor was upgraded in the packed-bed-tubular reactor, and the upgraded bio-oil was collected in a condensate collector. Char was collected in the pyrolysis vessel, and gas was calculated by difference. 2.5 Characterization of the bio-oils Bio-oil was separated into two phases—an organic phase and an aqueous phase by a separatory funnel. The organic phase of bio-oil was dehydrated using sodium sulfate salt prior undertaking proximate and ultimate analyses by elemental analyzer (TruSpec CHNSO, LECO Instruments) The degree of deoxygenation, an important parameter of the deoxygenation of PFC, can be calculated from Eq. (1), following the work of Oh et al. [19]: (1) Degree of deoxygenation ( DOD , % ) = ( 1 − − oxygen in oil / oxygen in PFC ) x 100 The elemental composition data were used for determination of the higher heating value (HHV) by applying Dulong's Eq. (2) [20,21]: (2) HHV ( MJ / kg ) = [ 338 . 2 C + 1442 . 8 ( H − O / 8 ) ] / 1000 Where C, H, and O = weight percent of C, H, and O from elemental analysis. The chemical composition of bio-oil (organic phase) was analyzed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, GC-MS (Model: Agilent 7890B GC system and 7000C GC/MS Triple Quad) with a HP-INNO Wax capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 µm) part no 19091S-433UI. The injector inlet temperature was kept at 220 °C and sample volume of 0.5 µl was injected in the split mode with split ratios of 50:1 and 10:1. Helium gas was used as a carrier gas at a constant flow rate of 1 cm3/min. The initial oven temperature was programmed from 50 °C (3 min of holding time) to 90, 120 and 250 °C with heating rates of 10, 4 and 8 °C/min, respectively. The final temperature at 250 °C was held for 10 min. The mass spectrometer analysis was carried out in EI mode at the following operation conditions: transfer line of 250 °C, ion source of 230 °C and electron energy at 70 eV. The mass spectra were in range 33-450 m/z. The interpretation of chromatograms was based on NIST2011 library. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization BET analysis revealed that the calcined NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst has a surface area, a pore volume, and average pore diameter of 60.29 m2/g, 0.3447 cm3/g, and 22.8 nm compared to 276 m2/g, 1.08 cm3/g, and 10.02 nm, respectively, as reported by Kohli et al. [11]. The lower surface area comes from the γ-Al2O3 used. The γ-Al2O3 was used as received and its surface area was only 220 m2/g. After impregnation, Ni and Mo may have blocked some of the small pores of the γ-Al2O3, therefore, the NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface area was lessened. The small pore volume was not desirable but the large pore diameter was quite useful for the access of large molecules. Catalyst that possesses a large pore diameter, high pore volume, and good active metal dispersion is highly desirable for the bio-oil upgrading. The study of Kohli et al. [11] has shown that the highest hydrotreating and hydrocracking conversions were observed with the NiMo/γ-Al2O3 while NiMo/SBA-15 and NiMo/activated carbon which had about twice surface area had lower activities. Analysis of NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by SEM and EDS produced images of the catalyst and metal dispersion as shown in Figs. 2 and 3 . At the magnifications of 50,000x and 100,000x (in Fig. 2), the catalyst can be seen to be made up of rough clusters of rounded solid particles. Each particle was about 20 micrometers in size. Fig. 3. (a-d) shows distributions of O, Al, Ni, and Mo, respectively. Oxygen and aluminum are the main chemicals in the support. Ni and Mo show good distributions all over the support (a desirable property for the upgrading). From elemental analysis of NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst by SEM-EDS and XRF, it was found that weight percentages of Ni were 8.08 and 8.93 (theoretical Ni of 10 wt%), and of Mo were 7.03 and 6.90 (theoretical Mo of 10 wt%), respectively. The XRD pattern of the fresh calcined NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is shown in Fig. 4 . From γ-Al2O3 pattern (ICDD Card No. 00-056-0457), it shows diffraction peaks at 2θ = 19.58°, 31.94°, 37.60°. 39.49°, 45.79°, 60.45°, and 66.76°. In Fig. 4, it can be seen that the γ-Al2O3 support exhibits some broad crystalline peaks at 2θ = 32.9°, 39.8°, 46.8° and 66.4°, which fits most of the XRD standard pattern of the cubic γ-Al2O3 phase. For molybdenum, the XRD pattern of a monoclinic structure of NiMoO4 shows diffraction peaks at 2θ = 23.9°, 25.3°, 28.8°, 32.6°, 38.7°, 41.2°, 43.9°, 47.4°, and 53.3°. The XRD pattern of our NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst consists of peaks at 2θ = 28.1°, 32.8°, 43.8°, and 47.4°. The XRD standard pattern of NiO shows 2θ = 37.4°, 45.7°, 50.3°, 60.9°, 61.1°, 66.4°, 67.2° and 69.9°. Our catalyst shows NiO peaks at 2θ = 45.8°, 61.1°, 67.2° and 69.6°. Sharifi et al. [30] reported the presence of NiO cubic structure (JCPDS 01-073-1519) as indicated by diffraction at 2θ = 37.3°, 43.3°, 63.0°, 75.6° and 79.6°. In addition, Cai et al. [31] reported that 2θ of NiO (JCPDS 65-6920) showed at 37.4°, 43.3°. 63.0°, and 75.4°. The standard pattern of MoO3 shows 2θ = 23.3°, 25.7°, 27.3°, 33.7°, 38.9°, 46.3°, 52.7°, 57.6°, and 58.8°. The crystalline orthorhombic phase of MoO3 in our catalyst is clearly seen from peaks at 2θ = 23.3°, 25.7°, 27.3°, 34.3°, 39.6°, and 49.2°. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) of NiMo oxide supported on γ-Al2O3 is shown in Fig. 5 . TPR profile of the NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited two major peaks. The first peak appeared at 475°C (360–600°C) while the second peak appeared approximately at 700°C (640–780°C). The total amount of H2 consumed in reduction up to 700°C is 21.335 mmol/ g catalyst and the reduction is 81%. TPR of Ni/Al2O3 and Mo/Al2O3 catalysts has been studied by Qu et al. [10] and reported that hydrogen reduction of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst started approximately at 500°C–860°C. TPR of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited two peaks at 641°C and 762°C while Mo exhibited two major peaks at 422°C (335°C–640°C) and 874°C (640°C–970°C). It is worth noting that reduction temperatures of nickel oxides may overlap with those of molybdenum oxides. Thyssen et al. [32] found that, in general, nickel oxide has a reduction temperature of about 360°C. In the work of Grams et al. [33] the TPR profile of Ni/Al2O3 showed reduction at a temperature slightly above 400°C, Ni/CeO2 at about 300°C, and Ni/ZrO2 at about 400–600°C. At a reduction temperature of about 410°C, the interaction between nickel compounds and the alumina support in the amorphous phase was weak. At temperatures above 850°C, a stronger interaction occurred, resulting in a structure of nickel aluminate (NiAl2O4) [34]. The first peak of NiMo/γ-Al2O3 in this study appeared at 475°C (360–600°C), it could be related either to Mo and/or Ni. The reduction of MoO3 with H2 was observed at 400–650°C and 650–1000°C [35]. Comparison with conventional TPR of Mo, Lin et al. [35] mentioned that the first reduction range corresponds to the change of MoO3 to MoO2 and the second temperature range at 650–1000°C is attributable to the reduction of MoO2 to Mo. Anas and Yusuff [36] suggested that even though MoO2 became Mo at a reduction temperature between 800 and 950°C, at temperature as high as 850°C, new phases might occur—for example, NiAl2O4. Due to the strong interaction of metal oxides on support at high temperatures, doped metal oxides could not be completely reduced [34]. Thus, in this work, the catalysts were reduced at 700°C. Fig. 6 shows the desorbed NH3 (NH3 pre-adsorbed at 150 °C) as the temperature increases at a rate 10 °C/min of the NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2, NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2, and NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 catalyst samples. The maximum desorption rate was between 150 and 400 °C and then gradually decreased until temperature reached 800 °C. The total acidity was established by accounting for the total amount of NH3 desorbed from the catalyst. The total acidity of each catalyst was investigated from the integration of desorbed NH3, as given by the TCD profiles. For the addition of CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2 to the NiMo/γ-Al2O3, the NH3 desorption of different mixtures are slightly different. The amount of NH3 desorbed from NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 was the highest and that from NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 was close to that from NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2. This implies that NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 was the most acidic catalyst and the acidity of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 is close to that of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2. The maximum NH3-desorption temperatures are 235 °C, 243 °C, and 335 °C, for NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2, NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2, and NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2, respectively. The NH3 desorption peaks at temperatures of 100–250 °C, 250–400 °C and ≥400 °C correspond with the weak acid, moderate acid, and high acid strength, respectively [17]. Based on the maximum peaks at different temperatures, the NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 and NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 are considered weak acid catalysts while NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 corresponds with moderate acid catalyst [9]. TiO2 which is well-known as a weak acid support covered the acid sites of NiMo/γ-Al2O3, therefore the NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 became weak acid catalyst. Some studies reported that a weak acid support with Lewis acid sites from TiO2 reduced coke formation or cracked products [21]. 3.2 Analysis of raw material It was found that the palm fruit cake consisted of 4.34% moisture, 85.16% volatile matter, 3.72% ash, and 6.78% fixed carbon. The C, H, N, and O in wt% were 47.53, 6.40, 1.19, and 44.88, respectively. Accordingly, the average chemical composition of palm fruit cake was CH1.62O0.71N0.02. The H/C and O/C molar ratios were equal to 1.62 and 0.71, respectively. Moreover, PFC consists of 20.8% cellulose, 16.4% hemicellulose and 19.0% lignin by weight. Its higher heating value and lower heating value were 17.02 and 15.80 MJ/kg, respectively. Thermal analysis of palm fruit cake was observed by thermogravimetric analyzer. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) profiles of palm fruit cake are shown in Fig. 7 . Weight loss in a temperature range 85–100°C was due to vaporization of moisture, which amounted to approximately 5%. The first peak of decomposition was in a temperature interval of 280–340°C, the second one 320–375°C, and the third one 380–600°C. These decomposition peaks are consistent with those of hemicellulose (220–350°C), cellulose (325–375°C), and lignin (200–700°C), as reported by Uzun et al. [37]. The pyrolysis temperature in this work was varied in a range 400–500°C due to low mass loss beyond 500°C, and the optimum pyrolysis temperature for the highest organic liquid yield was further investigated. 3.3 Products from pyrolysis of PFC Product yields from pyrolysis of PFC in a fixed-bed reactor with a heating rate of 5°C/min and final pyrolysis temperatures of 400, 450, and 500°C under N2 atmosphere are shown in Fig. 8 . Liquid product (bio-oil) was separated into two phases: aqueous phase and organic phase. At the pyrolysis temperatures of 400, 450, and 500°C, liquid product yields were 44.33, 44.71, and 41.00, respectively. The lower liquid product yield with increasing temperature was from the greater decomposition of liquid to gases. The increase in gas yield with increasing temperature was noticeable. At the pyrolysis temperatures of 400, 450, and 500°C, organic liquid product yields were 11.04, 12.46, and 11.13 wt%, respectively, and the char yields were 33.15, 31.15 and 31.13 wt%, respectively. There is an optimum pyrolysis conditions: high heating rate, short residence time, and intermediate temperature to reduce secondary reactions. As temperature increases, liquid yield decreases, however, liquid product contains two phases: aqueous phase and organic phase. Many reactions occur during pyrolysis including cracking, decarboxylation, decarbonylation, dealkylation, polymerization, water-gas shift reactions, and etc. At high temperature the water-gas shift reaction rate increases. It is possible that more water produced was used in the water-gas shift reaction with increasing temperature, resulting in a decrease in aqueous phase at high temperature. Moreover, secondary cracking occurs at high temperature and reduces organic liquid. The lower amount of organic liquid at 500 °C than that at 450 °C was observed, therefore, the optimum temperature for this experiment is at 450 °C. Jeong et al. [38] performed fast pyrolysis of palm kernel cake and the highest bio-oil yield, approximately 63 wt%, was obtained at a reaction temperature of 401 °C. We did not perform fast pyrolysis, however, it can be confirmed that fast pyrolysis produced high liquid yield. Different parts of oil palm tree produced less bio-oil. Sulaiman and Abdullah [39] performed fast pyrolysis of palm fruit bunch at 450 °C and produced the maximum bio-oil yield of 55%. The char yield decreases as the temperature increases. This could result from greater primary decomposition of biomass at a higher temperature or secondary decomposition of the char [40]. Gas yield has a tendency to increase at higher temperatures. At 400, 450, and 500°C, the gas yields were 23.51, 24.14 and 27.87%, respectively. The gas yield increased as the temperature increased due to the secondary cracking reaction of the pyrolysis vapor and the decomposition of the char. The highest liquid yield and organic phase yield were obtained at a pyrolysis temperature of 450°C. Thus, this temperature was selected as the pyrolysis temperature and used for investigation of the effect of different catalysts on pyrolysis vapor upgrading. Bio-oil from pyrolysis of palm fruit cake at 450°C was analyzed to determine its properties. Table 1 shows the elemental analysis of palm fruit cake in this study, palm kernel cake [38], palm empty fruit bunches [39], and bio-oil from pyrolysis of palm fruit cake at a temperature of 450°C. It seems that palm fruit cake in our study has the poorest properties for the lowest C content and the highest O content. The C, H, N, and O of the bio-oil produced were 68.45%, 9.43%, 1.21%, and 20.91%, respectively. It can be seen that C, H, and N of the bio-oil produced were relatively higher than those of the palm fruit cake, while O was lower after the O content was removed as CO, CO2, and H2O from the pyrolysis process. The H/C and O/C molar ratios were equal to 1.65 and 0.23, respectively. The higher heating value (32.85 MJ/kg) and lower heating value (30.79 MJ/kg) were much higher than those of PFC. The bio-oil compounds were identified by GC-MS analysis and classified based on their chemical structures and functional groups as acids, phenols, esters, aromatics, hydrocarbons, ketones, aldehydes, ethers, alcohols, or N-compounds. The main components of bio-oil are shown in Table 2 . Acids are the main components of the bio-oil. The acid yield was up to 39.21%; it causes corrosiveness and a reduction in heating value. Phenol and its derivatives were31.55%, esters 9.36%, aromatics 7.69%, hydrocarbons 6.48%, alcohols 3.01%, ketones 2.14%, N-compounds 0.29%, and ethers 0.27%. The crude bio-oil was not suitable for use as transportation fuel and needed to be improved in its properties. 3.4 Upgrading of the bio-oil Table 3 shows the product yields from catalytic pyrolysis of palm fruit cake at 450°C using different catalysts. Ni/γ-Al2O3, Mo/γ-Al2O3, and NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts provided 32.11–32.84% solid, 43.93–44.80% liquid, and 22.35–23.96% gas. The liquid product was separated into two phases: aqueous phase and organic phase. Among Ni/γ-Al2O3, Mo/γ-Al2O3, and NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst gave the highest amount of organic phase (13.22 wt%), while NiMo/γ-Al2O3 gave a slightly lower value (12.76 wt%) and the lowest one was from Ni/γ-Al2O3 (11.73 wt%). The differences in organic liquid yield using Ni/γ-Al2O3, Mo/γ-Al2O3, and NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts may come from different pathways of reaction. Kubička and Kaluža [41] studied deoxygenation of vegetable oils over sulfided Ni, Mo and NiMo catalysts. The double bonds in triglycerides, the main components of vegetable oils, are at first saturated and then they are converted into fatty acids that can either (i) undergo further hydrogenation or (ii) undergo decarboxylation. Differences in reaction pathway consequently cause difference in the product distribution. They found that catalysts exhibited significantly different product distributions. Upgrading of bio-oil is quite complex and consists of many reactions. The Ni/γ-Al2O3, Mo/γ-Al2O3, and NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts can undergo different reaction pathways, resulting in different organic liquid yields. Besides liquid yield, the quality of the organic liquid is also important. Acid sites measured in ammonia TPD studies were reported by Puron et al. [43] that NiMo loading resulted in a decrease in strong acidity of alumina. The increase in weak acidity upon NiMo loading might be related to the decrease in strong acidity occurred when metals covered the surface of Al2O3 and blocked acid sites and affected the cracking and hydrogenation activity. By adding CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2 to NiMo/γ-Al2O3, the organic phase yields are in range 10.95–14.01 wt%. The highest organic phase yield was obtained from NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 (14.01%). The increase in organic phase in the presence of ZrO2 may come from the weaker acid property of ZrO2 than that of Al2O3 (stronger bond). TPD results from the study of Lin et al. [35] showed no significant desorption for Al2O3 while ZrO2 exhibited at least three peaks. Moreover, the area of the TPD peaks of ZrO2 was greater than that of Al2O3. This means that species could be released from the ZrO2 surface more easily than from Al2O3 due to a weaker bond [35]. The additions of CeO2, TiO2 and ZrO2 facilitate NH3 desorption. The organic phase yields obtained as a decrease order: NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 (14.01%) > NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 (12.86%) > NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 (11.69%). From Fig. 6. NH3-TPD of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 shows highest NH3 desorbed, followed by NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2, and NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2. NH3 desorption area of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 is close to that of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2. Based on the maximum desorption temperature, the NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 and NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 are considered weak acid catalysts and NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 is moderate acid catalyst. The acidity of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 at moderate temperature (300-400 °C) promotes decomposition of the biomass at this temperature range, resulting in high organic liquid yield. NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 and NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 catalyst are both weak acid catalysts and desorbed NH3 at the same low temperature range (200-250 °C), the higher acidity of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 may be the reason for the higher organic liquid yield than that of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2. This shows that NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 was the best catalyst for producing the organic phase yield of bio-oil. Elemental analysis showed that Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Mo/γ-Al2O3 provided C, H, N, and O contents almost identical to those obtained without the use of catalyst. NiMo/γ-Al2O3 gave slightly higher C and lower O contents—69.79 and 19.30 wt%, respectively—as shown in Table 4 . For deoxygenation of the bio-oil without catalyst, and using Ni/γ-Al2O3, Mo/γ-Al2O3, and NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, the %DOD were in the range 53.41–57.00%. The highest %DOD was from NiMo/γ-Al2O3. Kubička and Kaluža [41] who studied deoxygenation of rapeseed oils at 260–280°C using sulfided Ni, Mo, and NiMo catalysts reported that NiMo/Al2O3 yielded a mixture of decarboxylation and hydrodeoxygenation hydrocarbon products while Ni/Al2O3 yielded only decarboxylation hydrocarbon products and Mo/Al2O3 yielded almost exclusively hydrodeoxygenation hydrocarbon products. They found that the activity of the catalyst decreased in the order sulfided NiMo/Al2O3 > sulfided Mo/Al2O3 > sulfided Ni/Al2O3. Their results are consistent with our work. In our study, NiMo/γ-Al2O3 was selected as the main catalyst as it provided high organic phase yield and the highest %DOD. NiMo/γ-Al2O3 was mixed with different metal oxides (CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2), and the catalyst effect on yields, %DOD of the bio-oil and other properties were investigated. The elemental compositions of bio-oils upgraded by NiMo/γ-Al2O3, NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2, NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2, and NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 are shown in Table 4. NiMo/γ-Al2O3 slightly improved the quality of the catalyst-free bio-oil. Most of the catalysts increased %C and decreased %O, especially NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2. %C, H, N, and O of the upgraded bio-oils were in the ranges 68.26–75.69, 9.04–10.01, 1.18–1.87, and 13.08–20.84, respectively. NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 seems to be a good catalyst for providing organic phase of bio-oil with the highest %C (75.69), the lowest %O (13.08), and the highest HHV (36.83 MJ/kg). The effects of NiMo/γ-Al2O3 mixed with CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2 catalysts on %DOD of the bio-oil and other properties were investigated. NiMo/γ-Al2O3, the main catalyst, provided %DOD of 57.00. However, NiMo/γ-Al2O3/metal oxides (CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2) yielded %DOD from 58.91 to 70.86. The highest %DOD (70.86) was obtained from NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2, and the second highest one was from NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2. From NH3-desorption area, the moderate acidity ZrO2 acts in synergy with NiMo/γ-Al2O3 increasing the catalyst deoxygenation activity. Compositions of liquid products from upgrading of the pyrolysis vapors by different catalysts are shown in Table 5 . Comparison of bio-oil produced using NiMo/γ-Al2O3/metal oxide (TiO2, ZrO2 and CeO2) catalysts with the crude bio-oil (without catalyst), revealed that using NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 caused reductions of acid and phenol, and increases in ketones, esters, aromatics, and hydrocarbons. The decrease in acid (up to 37%, from 39.21to 24.58 %) and increase in ketone products indicates possible ketonization of acetic acid, in which two acetic acid molecules condense to a molecule of acetone, CO2 and H2O [42] as in Eq (3): (3) Aromatic compounds and hydrocarbons were highest in the presence of ZrO2. Compared to the crude bio-oil, the aromatics and hydrocarbons were increased by 53% (from 7.69 to 11.79 %) and 89% (from 6.48 to 12.27 %), respectively. This is consistent with the work of Grams et al. [33], in which the largest amount of aromatics was produced from Ni/ZrO2. The use of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 catalyst resulted in slightly increase in esters. The decrease in phenol and increase in ester were by 8% and 6%, respectively. NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 reduced acid, phenols, and esters, and increased ketones, aromatics, and hydrocarbons. However, the performance of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 was slightly inferior to that of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 insofar as it gave lower reduction of phenol and lower amount of aromatics and hydrocarbons. In the work of Kaewpengkrow et al. [23], TiO2 (anatase) and Al2O3 were found to be more active than ZrO2 for increasing hydrocarbons and lowering oxygenated compounds; however, in this work, the addition of ZrO2 to NiMo/γ-Al2O3 revealed a better result than that obtained with the NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2. NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 was not good at acid reduction, but it is the best for phenol reduction. So far the best chemical composition was from NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 which gave low acids and phenols, and high aromatics and hydrocarbons in the organic phase of liquid product. 3.5 Catalyst deactivation The hydrodeoxygenation of phenol (a bio-oil model compound) occurs through a bifunctional mechanism, requiring a metallic site for hydrogenation/dehydrogenation together with an acid site of the support for dehydration [43]. In general, strong acid catalysts resulted in high cracking and high coke formation. Coke deposits were significantly affected by the hydrogenation capacity of the catalysts [44]. Puron et al. [44] found that catalyst with less hydrogenation activity but high cracking rate showed high solid yield. The amount of carbon deposited on the catalyst surface is shown in Fig. 9 . In our study coke found on Ni/γ-Al2O3, Mo/γ-Al2O3 and NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were 15, 60, and 63 wt%, respectively. Wang et al. [45] reported surface acidity from TPD of Ni/Al2O3 that showed high weak acid site and exhibited hydrogenation activity, the weak acid catalyst had low carbon deposited on the catalyst surface. Kubička and Kaluža [41] reported that Ni/Al2O3 showed decarboxylation activity, Mo/Al2O3 showed hydrodeoxygenation activity while NiMo/Al2O3 showed both decarboxylation and deoxygenation activity. This explained why low carbon deposited on the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst and higher coke deposited on NiMo/γ-Al2O3 and Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, moreover, NiMo/γ-Al2O3 had slightly higher carbon deposited than that on Mo/γ-Al2O3. Coke deposition on NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2, NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 and NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 were 47, 60, and 57 wt%, respectively. NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 reduced coke formation by gasification of deposited carbon promoted by CeO2 (due to a good oxygen storage capacity of CeO2) [46]. Coke deposition on NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 is close to that of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2. NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 has been reused once, organic liquid yield decreased from 12.99 to 11.65%, oxygen content increased from 13.70 to 20.71%, and HHV decreased from 35.77 to 32.52 MJ/kg which are close to those from pyrolysis without using catalyst as shown in Table 6 . The addition of metal oxides (CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2) to NiMo/γ-Al2O3 successfully improved activity of the NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst and lower coke formation. ZrO2 is the best metal oxide to mix with NiMo/γ-Al2O3 and CeO2 has tendency toward prolongation of catalyst lifespan due to low coke formation. 4 Conclusions The bimetal NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in reduced form shows higher activity than single metal catalyst for deoxygenation reaction. Ni acts as promoter to the Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst prepared by wet impregnation method, calcined at 500°C and reduced at 700°C was used as base catalyst to study effect of different metal oxides (CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2) on deoxygenation of pyrolysis vapor from palm fruit cake which was widely available from palm oil extraction industry. In this study the catalyst mixture was prepared by hand mixing metal oxides powder to the impregnated NiMo on γ-Al2O3 support. The metal oxides have shown to significantly improve the upgrading activity of the NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in different manners. The difference in their activities was related to the strength and type of acidity of the catalyst mixture. From NH3-TPD analysis, both NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 and NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 are weak acid while NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 is moderate acid. The area of TPD peaks of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 was the highest, suggesting species could be released from the NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 easily while the TPD peak of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 is close to that of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2. ZrO2 powder acts in synergy with NiMo/γ-Al2O3 increasing the catalyst deoxygenation activity. NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 was effective for deoxygenation reaction, acid reduction, and increasing aromatics and hydrocarbons, while NiMo/γ-Al2O3/TiO2 has slightly less activity than that of NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2. NiMo/γ-Al2O3/CeO2 was good at reductions of phenol and coke formation on the catalyst surface. Meanwhile, NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2 successfully produced liquid oil having properties and the calorific value close to those from the commercial diesel oil. Dear Editor-in-Chief I hereby submit a manuscript entitled “Deoxygenation of Pyrolysis Vapor from Palm Fruit Cake over NiMo/γ-Al2O3 Catalyst: Effect of CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2 Additives” to be considered for publication as a research paper in Journal of Molecular Catalysis (special issue: catalytic deoxygenation for the green biofuels). To the best of my knowledge, activities of NiMo/γ-Al2O3 mixed with metal oxides (CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2) has not been reported. Addition of CeO2 was found to reduce phenol and coke formation on catalyst surface while additions of TiO2 and ZrO2 increase aromatics and hydrocarbons. All the catalyst mixtures removed most oxygen from the crude bio-oil. I believe this finding will be of interest to the readers of your journal. I also declare that this manuscript is original and I agree that it should be submitted to the Journal of Molecular Catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Deoxygenation of pyrolysis vapor from palm fruit cake by different catalysts was prior investigated by using Ni/γ-Al2O3, Mo/γ-Al2O3, and NiMo/γ-Al2O3 prepared by wet impregnation method. NiMo/γ-Al2O3 showing the highest degree of deoxygenation (%DOD) activity was subsequently mixed with metal oxides: CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2. Effects of the catalysts on upgrading of pyrolysis vapor from palm fruit cake at 450°C under N2 atmosphere in a semi-batch process were investigated. The oil products were analyzed for CHNO elements by elemental analyzer, chemical compositions by a gas chromatograph coupled to a mass spectrometer (GC-MS), and higher heating values (HHV) by Dulong's equation. Catalysts have been characterized and discussed related to the product yields and properties. Acidity and acid strength of the catalyst mixture play an important role on the products. NiMo/γ-Al2O3 improved properties of the crude bio-oil by increasing organic phase yield, %DOD, and HHV. Addition of CeO2 to NiMo/γ-Al2O3 reduced phenol compound in the liquid products while addition of TiO2 to NiMo/γ-Al2O3 provided high aromatics and hydrocarbons comparable to those obtained from NiMo/γ-Al2O3/ZrO2. Addition of ZrO2 to NiMo/γ-Al2O3 exhibited the highest organic phase yield (%), %DOD (71%), and HHV (37 MJ/kg).
coredata.dc:title: Deoxygenation of pyrolysis vapor from palm fruit cake over NiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst: Effect of CeO2, TiO2, and ZrO2 additives
